comments.body:
the top level intersection is sufficient. so: 
`T &  { [k in keyof T]: Spy; }`

as mentioned in the linked issue #21305 the `ArrayLikeMatchers` did not accept the type returned by `jasmine. arrayContaining()`

because of that I added the `ArrayContaining<T>` type

in jasmine 2.8 the `nothing()` matcher was added 

this change makes the `actual` parameter optional as the usage is `expect().nothing`

see https://github.com/jasmine/jasmine/issues/1221

this was reason for this change

we'll need to support both uses

as the documentation states that you can call it either without any argument or with both `files` and `filterString` I'd propose to add a overload with the parameters both set and one without 

```
execute(): any;
execute(files: string[], filterString: string): any;
```

although I could not find any reference to `filterString` in the actual code
https://github.com/jasmine/jasmine/blob/master/src/core/Env.js#L262

I agree with the proposed change.

I thought these were typings definitions for https://github.com/jasmine/jasmine-npm (where both parameters do have an effect), since it says on the [README.md](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped) of DefinitelyTyped
>For an NPM package "foo", typings for it will be at "(at)types/foo"

and you install jasmine-npm on npm by typing
```
npm install jasmine
```

See also https://www.npmjs.com/package/jasmine.
This is kind of confusing.
So what are these typings for if not for the npm package `jasmine`?
Should the same change be applied here (i.e. `methodNames: SpyObjMethodNames<T>`)?
